stories.text:
I've long struggled with my retention rates. Especially for the free to paid retention rates.

I've tried in-app tutorials, email welcome sequences, and trying to arrange calls with customers.

Just so I could try to build a relationship so they could ask me questions and I could get them onboarded properly... But none of these was a home run.

Then I had the idea to create a way to send personalized thank you videos at scale.

Each time a user signs up for your app you get a to-do item to send them a personal video which gets sent to their inbox. The user can then click an email link to a webpage with your video. A new one is recorded each time so your new users each get an ultra-personal email right in their inbox.

With everyone being flooded with generic emails (just using their name at the top isn't enough) you can really stand out and show your customer that you're here for them.

Imagine getting a personal thank you from Jeff Bezos every time you sign up for AWS?

I think this is a really cool idea. But who knows, let me know what you think

BTW I created a landing page to catch any of you that would be interested: https://signup.thankyoureels.com/saas/beta
stories.title: Roast Me: Way to boost free to paid conversion at some scale?

stories.text:
I'm planning to participate in LangJam: https://github.com/langjam/langjam

The theme hasn't been released yet, but since everything compiles to assembly eventually, I'm already planning on building a new macro assembly assuming assemblies will be relevant no matter the theme.

I have ~2 months in a ~15 year career doing assembly, so it's way outside my sweet spot. However, I think I have a unique perspective, where I'm approaching all languages now as ones that can be edited in a spreadsheet GUI (as well as plain text editors and IDEs). If you want to see a (crappy—my video production skills need work) demo of what I mean, one is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0l2QWH-iV3k

I've done some Googling around, and found this thread on HN where apparently Sony was encouraging devs to use spreadsheets to write better assembly for the PS3: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=12294685

Was wondering if anyone out there has experience with things like this, and could share some more leads?

Also, if you like PL design check out LangJam this Friday! I'm excited for it.
